node.title: Covid: England ending isolation laws and mass free testing
node.description: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson has announced all Covid restrictions will end in England this week and free mass testing will stop from 1 April.

node.title: New strong wool industry body aims to grow sector's profits
node.description: New Zealand strong wool farmers, growers, manufacturers and exporters have joined forces to establish the industry group Wool Impact NZ.

node.title: Woman sues LAPD after she was wrongfully arrested and spent two weeks in jail
node.description: Police are accused of mistaking Bethany K. Farber for another suspect with the same name.

node.title: Tiwai Point smelter deal contributes to dip in Meridian's first-half profit
node.description: Meridian has reported a drop in first-half profit reflecting negative changes in the value of hedge instruments as well as a drop in revenue from Tiwai Point Aluminium Smelter.

node.title: 'Very confusing, very quickly': Luxon wants pathway beyond peak of Omicron
node.description: The government needs to front up on when vaccine mandates will be removed, the National Party leader says. Audio

node.title: Muslims remain at risk of being targeted by terrorists within NZ, coroner told
node.description: The Islamic Women's Council has told a coronial hearing into the Christchurch mosque attacks that Muslims are still in danger of being targeted by terrorists in New Zealand.

node.title: Rapid antigen tests adopted as main Covid-19 test for Aucklanders
node.description: Rapid Antigen Tests are being used as the primary test at Auckland community testing centres from today to help meet demand for testing as the Omicron outbreak grows.

node.title: 'We were gutted': Studies disrupted as Covid-19 spreads at universities
node.description: Lectures started at some universities this week and the Union of Students' Associations said there had been cases of the virus among students at several institutions.

node.title: PCR testing 'inundated', labs look ahead to phase three
node.description: Testing laboratories say they have been inundated with demand for Covid-19 PCR tests much faster than expected, and there's a major backlog in Auckland. Audio

node.title: Mobile revenue helps drive half-year profit rise for Spark
node.description: A lift in mobile revenue, lower depreciation costs and falling finance expenses have boosted Spark's bottom line.

node.title: National pushes for law to sanction Russia over Ukraine actions
node.description: The National Party wants a law change that will enable New Zealand to place sanctions on Russia outside of the United Nations' process.

node.title: Putin recognises Ukraine rebel regions as independent
node.description: Russian President Vladimir Putin has recognised two breakaway regions in eastern Ukraine as independent entities and ordered Russian peacekeepers into the area upping the ante in a crisis the West…

node.title: Epidemiologist's warning: 'A serious disease that people need to take seriously'
node.description: There's "no doubt" New Zealanders are not taking Omicron seriously, Auckland epidemiologist Rod Jackson says, adding that in the US, it has killed more people than the Delta variant. Audio

node.title: What will the return of the big OE mean for employers?
node.description: The Detail - With MIQ soon to be a thing of the past, young people who have put off international travel during the pandemic are planning their OE.

node.title: Man who died in Nelson knew person who allegedly shot him
node.description: Detective Inspector Mark Chenery says the two parties are known to each other and police are satisfied there is minimal risk to the wider community.

node.title: RNZ, TVNZ merger decision made by Cabinet
node.description: RNZ understands that a decision has been made by Cabinet on whether the merger of TVNZ and RNZ into a new public media entity will go ahead.

node.title: Protest funder working for university forced to close campus
node.description: The chief executive of a company working with Victoria University of Wellington on a re-development is helping fund the very protest which has forced one of its campuses to close.

node.title: How the Ukraine crisis is already hitting Americans' wallets
node.description: With higher gas prices, inflation and supply-chain shocks, the conflict in Europe is spilling over into the U.S. economy.

node.title: Big majorities reject book bans - CBS News poll
node.description: Most say teaching about the history of race in America promotes understanding.

node.title: Woman loses $390,000 in online crypto dating scam
node.description: A new report finds in 2021, cryptocurrency scam victims lost more than $7.7 billion.

node.title: Northern areas could see 4000 cases a day during Omicron peak - modelling
node.description: The peak of Covid-19 in the Omicron outbreak in Auckland and Northland could reach 4000 daily cases, if transmission is low, or 9000 if it is not, new modelling shows.

node.title: CareCube accused of scamming people who got COVID-19 tests
node.description: Lawsuit alleges clinic overcharged New Yorkers for COVID-19 tests and billed for doctor visits that never took place.

node.title: Amelia Kerr stars as White Ferns keep winning
node.description: White Ferns rain-delayed match against India in Queenstown turns into high-scoring 20-over hit out.

node.title: How Peloton's Robin Arzón used stunning obstacles as fuel for greatness
node.description: From a shocking diagnosis of type one diabetes to being held hostage at gunpoint, Robin Arzón has not had an easy life. But she hasn't let any of the obstacles stop her — and now she's an inspiration to millions.

node.title: Christchurch terror attacks: Coronial hearing continues with more submissions
node.description: Islamic groups and first responders are expected to make submissions to the coroner's scope hearing on the Christchurch terror attacks today.

node.title: Wellington local says he witnessed 'violent' assault at Parliament protest
node.description: A man who says he witnessed an assault by two protesters on another occupier at Parliament says it shows how the mood has turned nasty at times this week.

node.title: Mercury Energy posts nearly $300m net profit increase
node.description: Mercury says its first half result reflects a period of significant change for the company, including becoming New Zealand's largest wind generator.

node.title: PGG Wrightson's posts record half-year profit
node.description: The country's biggest rural services company said it had overcome market volatility and disrupted supply chains to make the most of booming agricultural exports.

node.title: Cryptocurrency prices plunge as Ukraine crisis intensifies
node.description: Investors are shunning bitcoin and other digital currencies in favor of traditional safe-haven assets like gold.

node.title: Govt backing for plan to extract lithium from geothermal brine
node.description: A geothermal lithium firm has attracted government investment into a new method to harvesting the metal, which is essential for many technologies.
